official-title.#text: To direct the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board to develop accessibility guidelines for electronic instructional materials and related information technologies in institutions of higher education, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

short-title.#text: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Guidelines for accessible electronic instructional materials and related information technologies in institutions of higher education

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board

quote.#tail: ) shall develop guidelines for the accessibility of electronic instructional materials and related information technologies in institutions of higher education. Such guidelines shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this Act referred to as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 502 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

text.#text: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the
include performance criteria to ensure that such materials and technologies are accessible to covered blind individuals and covered individuals with a disability; and
be consistent with the standards for technical and functional performance criteria issued pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 508(a)(2)(A)(ii) of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall, to the extent practicable, ensure that the guidelines issued under
are consistent with national and international accessibility standards for electronic instructional materials and related information technologies.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act/s:2/ss:a

text.#text: The

header.#text: Harmonization with national and international standards

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act/s:2/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall review and, as appropriate, amend such guidelines to reflect technological advances or changes in electronic instructional materials and related information technologies.

text.#text: Not later than 3 years after the effective date of the guidelines described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be deemed to be in compliance with the non-discrimination provisions
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act/s:2

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: III of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990

external-xref.#tail: ) with respect to the use of such materials or technologies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

text.#text: Institutions of higher education that use electronic instructional materials and related information technologies that comply with the accessibility guidelines described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: if the institution of higher education provides such materials or technologies, or an accommodation or modification, that would allow covered blind individuals and covered individuals with a disability to receive the educational benefits of such materials or technologies—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act/s:2

text.#text: Nothing in this Act shall be construed to require an institution of higher education to use electronic instructional materials or related information technologies that conform to the accessibility guidelines described in

header.#text: Noncompliant electronic instructional materials and related information technologies

text.#text: in an equally effective and equally integrated manner as non-disabled or non-blind students; and
with substantially equivalent ease of use of such materials or technologies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Technology, Equality and Accessibility in College and Higher Education Act/s:2

text.#text: There is authorized to be appropriated such sums as may be necessary to carry out
In this Act the following definitions apply:

term.#tail: means an individual whose central visual acuity does not exceed 20/200 in the better eye with correcting lenses or whose visual acuity, if better than 20/200, is accompanied by a limit to the field of vision in the better eye to such a degree that its widest diameter subtends an angle of no greater than 20 degrees.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: mean a blind individual or an individual with a disability whose blindness or disability limits the ability of such individual to access electronic instructional materials and related information technologies.

text.#text: The terms

header.#text: Covered blind individual and covered individual with a disability

term.#tail: has the meaning given such term in

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 3 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990

term.#tail: has the meaning given such term in

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965

term.#tail: means digital curricular content including course-assigned books, journals, articles, and web pages, used by students, faculty, or administrative personnel of an institution of higher education to facilitate the teaching and learning process, including technologies used in distance education as defined in

text.#text: The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 103 of the Higher Education Act of 1965

text.#text: The term
means any electronic platform or delivery system used by students, faculty, or administrative personnel of an institution of higher education to access electronic instructional materials; and
includes any hardware, firmware, software, and applications required for the manipulation, annotation, and dissemination of such electronic instructional materials.
